What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned foundational understanding of moral philosophy as well as the difference/interaction with psychology.
basic knowledge of moral psychology, using moral reasoning to analyse one's intention etc.
I learned about the distinction between moral philosophy and moral psychology and how we can use psychology to help us be better people.

In the course of class discussions with the professor and ta, I have overturned many of my understandings of philosophy and social morality. As a student of international relations, many times we are more likely to relate to the different foreign policies of countries and international conflicts, which are more practical content and tend to overlook a lot of the common moral cognition as a human community. My interest lies in the exchange and mutual learning of various civilizations, and most of my research focuses on the similarities and differences between Chinese civilization and other diversified civilizations in the world, hoping that my research can explain something. Of course, in this course, I have gained friends from all over the world, and I have also gained a lot of discussions on moral issues in different cultural backgrounds. I truly feel the power of civilization, but more than anything else, what we have in common as a human community. To be sure, I do not think that the world of the future will be an ideal utopia, nor do I think that our current moral research will be the same ten, fifty, hundred years from now. But I am glad that we have a certain ability to explain our moral actions and thoughts on the road. This is the biggest shock of moral psychology to me.
Learned about how to view my personal beliefs on morality from different perspectives and understand others' views as well.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course is strong in terms of conversational engagement.
mixed form of classes is the top strength
The transition to reading mostly scientific papers in the second half of the course seemed a bit abrupt and I would have liked more discussion about those papers and how their findings are relevant.
Its great

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. It is a great starter for philosophy.
yes, a great course for extending one's interest field into psychology and cognitive science, a excellent way to make friends and contact with brilliant Yale students, the best professor of all time
I would recommend this course to a student interested in philosophy or psychology.
Yes, it opens up part of your mind that you haven't probably experienced before.

narratives.question_text: How will you use the knowledge and skills you learned in this course in your future endeavors?
comments: I'll think more complexly about morality and psychology.

everytime i would be in moral dillemas, everytime i would meet scenarios which is too hard to comprehense in a intuitive way, more thoughts into management practices and connetion with human kind in the future
I gained general knowledge about topics in philosophy and psychology.
I will use the knowledge from this course everyday.
